The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback

Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not

Strengths: Very interesting topic, one of the few courses at YSPH that are very applicable to students in the Health Care Management concentration, pace is fairly easy to keep up with
Weaknesses: A bit slow for students who are more familiar with Excel/math/these concepts

This class is very fun and I love the practical weekly homework cases. The cases help me think and develop analytical skills. Dr. Paltiel explains the cost-effective methods clearly. A perfect experience of this class. I really enjoyed and also learned a lot.

strengths: very interesting and stimulating questions and concepts by nature of the fact that there is not always a "correct" answer.  dynamic teacher!  real-world scenarios are valuable to prepping for entry into the job market.
weaknesses: small amount of feedback in addition to not posting answers to the midterms quickly made it difficult to evaluate how I went wrong.  I wish we had gone over midterm questions like we did with the HWs instead of having a class on extra material because I would feel more confident in my understanding upon exiting the course.  I was unable to go to the office hours because of work; having them on different days of the week might have made that better.

Very difficult course and takes a while to wrap your head around, but if you keep working at it and working with others, you can understand it! Really helps your strategic thinking. 

Would've liked more resources for understanding the homeworks prior to submitting.

Strengths- useful content, awesome lectures, learned valuable material for career
Weaknesses- length of exams

I really, really enjoyed this course. It was amazing and helped me think about problems in a new and critical way. One suggestion would be to have more TFs so that it would be possible to get more personal feedback on homework and exams.
Classes were very helpful, working with peers on HW was critical because a lot of this is self taught

Great professor, very positive and fun. However, he skips intermediate steps when solving many of the problems and train of thought is tough to follow. Would appreciate concrete answer keys for the homework assignments.

Overall, I think this was a great course that pushed me beyond my comfort zone. This is the first course I've taken on cost effectiveness & decision making so it was a very good, challenging introduction.

I loved this course. It's the first non-public health college course I've ever taken, and even this class used relevant examples from the public health world. I learned so much, and as an SBS student, I learned a lot of things I never would have thought about (diagnostic cutoffs, etc. - how these came to be, instead of just what they are).
good

Strengths: 1) Case studies you worked on before class in order to "jump-start" your brain into learning the material & then were covered in class (pass/fail, so no pressure to get the exactly right answer); 2) Professor 
Weakness: 1) Lack of personalized feedback 
Improvements: 1) Give the class more TFs!! We understand it is a large class, so giving feedback can be challenging. However, I think if there were more TFs devoted to the class giving personalized feedback would be doable. I think the material covered post-first midterm became more difficult and required more feedback.
supportive, great setting

- the class is great, my only feedback is that I the answer key after the exam wasn't the only review of the previous exam we got. It would be a great learning experience for me for the professor himself to go over the exam afterwards

-Strengths: It was a good introduction to thinking critically 
-Weaknesses: I wish the quality of the TA (continual office hours, more contact) were perhaps enhanced or the number of TAs for the large class size increased
weekly (optional) discussion section w TAs

instructor can very well engage the whole class.

content is too easy.
can be improved with more in-depth contents and be more quantitative
Great class, learned SO SO SO much.

strength: the course is very interesting even though some parts are hard.
weakness: could have more applications introduced.

Excellent course and exciting topic - it is great that lectures are recorded since the course runs a bit late. Professor Paltiel makes them worth watching though. I do think lectures and homeworks were helpful, however, the readings were a bit dense.

It is such a cool course. The professor does an amazing job teaching such a large class but still make it feel like we know him so well. I would say the strengths are that it is taught by professor Paltiel, and that the courses are recorded so that we can go back to review the particularly complex analyses.
This was my favorite course this semester. I learned so many useful skills.

Great course. The problem sets and the exams were fun to work through, and I could tell that the professor put a lot of effort into making these questions interesting. However, I felt like there were a few students who asked excessive amount of questions, in a way that did not even further our learning. It seemed like the professor tried to limit those kinds of questions, but in the future, I hope classroom discussions are more thought-provoking. Also, the class was way too large, and the administration should be ashamed of not providing us the education that we deserve.
good
It was an excellent introduction to the discipline of cost-effectiveness analysis, especially as someone who had little background in economic evaluation.
It was definitely an interesting course. I don't know if I learned any skill but it was fun

Really good course, definitely had some challenging aspects to it, which was nice. Sometimes the homeworks were a little difficult to do, even with the readings, but the fact that one could explain what they would do and that the homeworks were completion grades, made the learning experience good. Really like the fact the lectures are recorded, because some topics had to be studied a little extra.

great course with extremely relevant skills taught
the class size was too large and made instruction very impersonal. feedback was nearly non-existent
Great

I really enjoyed this course. Much of the material overlapped and connected well with other public health courses I am taking. The only weakness was the time of the course (once a week on Wednesday evenings) and how large of a class size. I think some of the exercises would have been much more enjoyable if we had a small enough class to really discuss the concepts.

Strengths - teaching style - chronology of the course, enthusiasm, real world application
Weaknesses - difficult to follow along with excel spreadsheets in lecture setting - potentially adding a lab might

I personally did not like the set up of the class.  Dr. Paltiel did give us fair warning about the set up at the beginning of the semester, saying that the course set up has mixed reviews, so I cannot hold it against him since the design was made clear from the start.  However, I benefit more from learning material THEN doing homework rather than learning how to do homework through readings then going back to learn about it.  I ended up having to go through all assignments fully twice for this reason, which wasted more of my time than was helpful to my learning.

I also felt some exam questions were unfair.  For example, the final exam had questions that were very different from examples we did in class.  We never did an example in these units or that was fully mutually exclusive, and I struggled figuring this out on my own.  I feel as though the exams need to be based more directly on class material.
great and very educational
course was great! Would have been nice to have a little more instruction going into the cases. It was pretty challenging to "self teach" a lot of this material.

Strengths: phenomenon instructor! Lectures were super engaging, clear, and organized. It was nice that the lectures were recorded so it was easy to access resources to do midterms and the final. The material was fun and interesting. The class overall was super fun and interesting. I learned so much about decision making and cost effectiveness analysis, and I thought these skills were helpful in the future. The homework was challenging, but since it was graded past/fail, there was less of a pressure on getting good grades than an effort to learn. 

Weaknesses: I didn't like how late the lecture was. I also think more practice problems would be nice so that students have opportunities to master the skills.

This was an excellent course overall. The problem sets each week were very well constructed, and I genuinely felt that I was understanding the material. The material was challenging enough for me to think critically about the issues listed. Additionally, there was a good deal of variation in the context of each week's assignment. Some were infectious diseases related, some were orthopedics, and some were amusing scenarios. Overall, the assignments were enjoyable.

The strengths of the course is each session could be found in Media Library on Canvas. Since this course ends really late in a day, for most of the time I just take the online courses and seldom show up in the classroom. I haven't found a weakness yet, but one suggestion is that I really hope the standard solution of each case will be provided after the assignment submission.
Great!

I was not a fan of this course.  While I can acknowledge that Professor Paltiel is personally very supportive and engaging the course lacks a lot of structure.  For example, the class was taken by 120+ students but it only had two TFs who interchanged availability for a single office hour each week.  It's unfair to tell students they have office hours as an option for academic support but then expect 120 students to share a 60 minute time frame.  This strategy also creates an unfair workload for the TFs.  This class easily should have received 4-6 TFs like many of the core courses that also teach 100+ students.  Also, the first few weeks Dr. Paltiel didn't teach the material until after the homework was due.  If we're expected to teach ourselves the material via the readings in order to do the homework then what are students paying YSPH $60,000/year for?  Halfway through the course he changed this strategy and started teaching concepts before introducing them as homework but this should have been consistent all year long.  I also wish the class offered sections to practice the concepts like Microeconomics and Epidemiology.  Math heavy courses at YSPH should provide opportunities for more intimate learning beyond the auditorium lectures.

Strengths: Required students to think very critically, excellent professor, useful skill
Weaknesses: Large class size, late class time, little feedback in regards to homework, tests returned back rather late
Improvement: Address the weaknesses, perhaps try and fit in more skills (I felt like we really only learned one or two concepts as a whole.)

I really loved this class! I think that this class was not only really great because it taught us the skills to run cost-effectiveness analyses on data that we encounter in the future but it was also really great at explaining what cost-effectiveness research is and how it relates to policy decisions today. I hadn't realized that some countries, e.g. the UK, use cost-effectiveness research to determine which drugs and treatments their national health service covers. The class was really great because it helped show us what small-scale changes could be made and large-scale policy changes could be made due to cost-effectiveness analyses. I also really appreciate that this class used primarily excel when teaching us how to do cost-effectiveness analyses because I think that makes it easier for us to learn the fundamentals and also to use other programming later when we have the foundations now. Overall, I really enjoyed this class and it taught me so many skills that I hope I'll be able to use even in the near future!
interesting and useful content, but can be more structured

everything is great, except that I dont understand the grading policy. You only get a H if you almost didnt make any mistakes throughout the whole semester, which seems to be discouraging. I know people give up on digging deeper or trying to understand whats the correct way because they wont get a H anyway
Great. This course introduced basic knowledge on cost-effectiveness analysis. It is very helpful.
The only problems I felt I could do were problems exactly like what we did in class. The knowledge was not transferable.

Overall, this was an excellent class. David Paltiel sets up the course so that everything builds up nicely. It is a wonderful introduction to cost-effectiveness analysis. The last few classes were a bit disjointed -- David said that they would be this way, so we knew to expect it. I feel really excited to take Reza Yaesoubi and Ed Kaplan's classes after this!
Excellent.  Wonderful instructor, would highly recommend to any MPH student.
Good introduction to CEA. Like the overall structure in terms of weekly assignments and very much appreciated how exams were administered.
great class

Strengths: know how to provide cost-effective solutions.
Weakness: the first half of the course is more like a college level probability course.  I really think a TF session to provide answer keys to homework is a better way to teach this course, instead of using the lecture time.
Great material, interesting and challenging assignments

overall the course is very interesting and engaging that incorporates theory and problems that relate to public health in a tangible way. the course itself was awesome though due to the class size, it may not have been the more effective way of implementing or teaching the course.
This course is excellent. While I was not very good at it, I learned a lot and am looking forward to taking similar courses during the rest of my time at YSPH.
Fantastic course, that covers a lot of important material.
This course was very interesting and the professor made it fun/engaging!

Strengths:
- Professor is incredibly engaging and understanding of students
- You'll learn exactly what you expect given the course name and description

Weaknesses:
- The timing! 5-7pm on a Wednesday night demotivates me from attending class in person

This is a great class that provides an opportunity to learn and practice decision making and cost-effectiveness analysis. As a joint-degree with SOM, some of the content was repetitive, but the exercises were exactly the right level of difficulty to get good practice with the concepts and try applying them to a range of different scenarios. The exams were honestly pretty fun, and I always finished them feeling like they were good learning opportunities if nothing else.

My only recommendation would be to broaden examples to a global scale. For better or worse, cost effectiveness is a huge part of global health right now, so using examples from LMICs would be interesting.
This course was my favourite of the semester. The topics were useful and relevant, and the homework engaged with the readings effectively.

I thought this class was very good. It provided me with a unique skill set. Classes were organized in an appropriate manner. One thing I found though was that classes could often get derailed by people asking off-topic questions. At times, this could throw off my concentration.
my favorite course!!!
This was an EXCELLENT course. Should be offered earlier and twice a week based on the professors depth and knowledge on the topic
Great class that introduces students to an important tool to evaluate public health interventions.
The professor was very enthusiastic about his topic and has a lot of experience in cost-effective analysis.
It is a good and practical class. The instructor taught this class really clear but not too deep.

Strengths: great introduction to cost-effectiveness research methods. Course is structured to begin with easy to grasp examples, followed by more applied problems in later lessons.

Weaknesses: given the breadth of experience of students entering the course, we often spend an extended amount of time on easier concepts in probability for those in the course without any background.

This is a great introduction into cost-effective analysis. Professor is great, entertaining, and good at explaining the concepts. Downside was the midterms. Often questions raised in the exams would ask us questions that were very different from what we learned in class or in assignments. More practice problems with answer keys to prepare would be helpful. Providing examples to cover the different ways calculations can be done would also be helpful. Also, the last 3 weeks of class didn't cover new material. I think it would have been better to spread out some of the concepts a little more over the 12 weeks, perhaps only having one midterm and one final so that we had time to practice and raise questions. By the time we got the first midterm back, the next one was due the following week, giving us one week to reach out to TF's or the professor with questions about the last one.
I liked the homework assignments as they really helped solidify the subject matter. I also liked that we reviewed the solutions in class.
This course is really interesting, which uses cases to let you understand how to do cost effectiveness analysis.

This course is well designed, from beginner level to intermediate level learning. I could grasp a taste of cost-effective analysis learning. 
While the studying curve might be steeper in the last half of the courses, and we are not required to master some of the lessons. This may be a little bit discouraging. Also, I hope to increase our ability to make cost-effective analysis in real-world, so I would like to be involved in some real projects, instead of calculation in cases of our homework. Also, I would prefer to learn more about any software could support us to conduct a cost-effective analysis.

Professor Paltiel is a phenomenal lecturer. He makes the time fly and is engaging despite the large clsss size. The material became a bit more difficult in the later half of the semester and cases topics varied, keeping things interesting. The exams were all long but extremely fair. This was by far my favorite course of the semester. However, TFs did not play a large role in my learning. Working with others on weekly homework helped solidify my understanding of the content.

The principles taught in this course are incredibly important, but the material was unapproachable at times and I felt that the expectations set for the course were confusing - this was most frustrating to me. 

I took this course on (as one of 6 classes) because I was so interested in the material - I was nervous, but comforted by the first class's reassurances that if you worked hard and put in effort you would get an HP. While this sort of held true on the homeworks (despite having to put in many many hours just to show you had tried!) the grading of the first exam was shocking. While partial credit was promised for explanations, explanations seemed ignored and it turned out that the reality was not as friendly as it was pitched. I get that it was a large class, and adjustments had to be made, and a high standard for coursework must be established, but this mismatch was distressing and for someone completely new to the material (although I am a second year!) it was paralyzing. Paired with an already busy semester and extremely limited office hours by the TAs for informal help (Fridays, in the afternoon - I had a conflict every single week, and was never surveyed about convenient times to hold office hours), this class was incredibly stressful and required a lot of effort to likely only receive a passing grade. I don't mean to be harsh, but I was surprised - I hope this feedback is helpful, and do believe that this is incredibly important subject material and that Prof Paltiel is a great educator!
Great course.  Interesting topic that is very well taught.  Lots of self-directed learning.

AP: Strengths: Provided me with a framework with which to approach decision making, and a basic understanding of cost-effectiveness analysis. 

Weaknesses: None

AP-
Excellent overview of CEA/DM. HIGHLY entertaining professor; stand-up comedy level.
More challenging first exam compared to other assessments, but rather straightforward assessments with useful course readings.
Although some may complain of the significant "self-teaching" component of the course, this is highly intentional, as the "AHA" moments throughout the course are well worth-it.
Really emphasized conceptual understanding of CEA/DM.

This was a very interesting course. I wished we spent less time on the probability trees and more time on the markov and monte carlo problems. Overall it was a very stimulating class with an interesting approach to homeworks that certainly aided my learning.
I think the course material is difficult and aside from maybe getting a bigger/better room, there's little room to improve this course.
Definitely felt like I learned a tangible skill in this class -- my excel skills have immensely improved and I definitely have learned a lot of cost-effectiveness in general.

Strengths: Prof. Paltiel manages to make a rather complicated subject approachable through incremental sessions that all build upon each other; Left feeling like I actually learned a skill, and a useful one at that; Lectures are super engaging; Homework was informative and fun, even.
Weaknesses: NA. This class is excellent.

The lectures are interesting, and the material in this course is presented in a digestible form. Many of the concepts in this class can be hard to grasp, but Professor Paltiel does a great job of explaining them well. I think the length and difficulty of the exams are fair. They test us on concepts we learned in the lecture and in our homework. The homework assignments prepared me for the exam, and I liked that the exam focused on testing us on concepts we practiced in the homework assignments. I think the exams were graded fairly, and I liked that they gave us partial credit on our answers. Lastly, I liked that all the exams were take home. I wish the course was at a different time. Having it at night makes scheduling difficult.
Great class and very useful in future.

Strengths: Having lectures recorded is so helpful! Also I appreciate that he goes slow and that homework is graded on completion
Weaknesses: I wish we could get feedback on homework (although I know that is hard with a class of this size) and that the TA's had better office hours.

The course material was very interesting and clearly applicable in 'real world' scenarios. The instructor was very knowledgeable and engaging. 
One weakness of the course was that I felt the class size was too big, I feel a smaller class size would be more conducive to learning. Also I sometimes found it difficult to find the continuity between lectures and the information presented.

Pros: Really useful skill set, taught extremely well, the best part is the video recording of the lecture. 


Cons: It was at an inconvenient time.

STRENGTHS
-- The amount of homework was exactly right. I have a relevant undergraduate degree, so it may have been easier for me than others. Still, I thought the amount of reading was no more and no less than what you needed to understand the important concepts. Some classes try to include so much that you end up not learning anything. This class did an excellent job of homing in on the most powerful concepts, and then making sure that they were presented clearly and reinforced regularly.
-- Course materials were on Canvas in advance. Although they might be edited closer to the time of the class, they were useful for reference and for getting a head start on assignments in advance of particularly busy weeks. The PowerPoints were well-organized.
-- Weekly homework assignments were relevant to the exams and helpful exercises.
-- The content of the course was illuminating and wide-ranging.
-- All classes at YSPH should be more like this class. It inspired me to think more about the questions raised in class.

WEAKNESSES
-- Weekly homework assignments should have been worth slightly more points, maybe 3 points each, to allow for incremental progress.
-- The course could have included 1 in-class quiz worth 15% of the overall grade, instead of 2 take-home quizzes. Homework assignments could be treated as mini-take-home quizzes, and then a single in-class quiz can weed out people who would use CourseHero instead of actually understanding the material.
-- To engage students with the material during class, set aside 5-10 minutes for students to work through simple questions in small groups, before sharing with the full class. This allows students to actively think through problems and then get immediate feedback from the professor on correct methods. The lectures were concise (which was great) so an added 5 minutes will be OK.
excellent
Great course, could have been more rigorous mathematically allowing us to walk away with a more refined skill set.
Overall, this course teaches very important concepts and skills.  However, the homework and exams were sometimes extremely difficult and time consuming.
excellent course!

This is a provoking course. I like the structure of the course which encouraged me to think more and more. I think the assessment was somewhat unfair. Midterms and Final took up 90 percent of the grade. For each exam, there were only several questions which worth a lot of points. But sometimes the questions were vague.

Strengths are that Professor Paltiel is clearly an expert in the field and has the knowledge to back it up. It's a fun class and the learning doesn't feel onerous. Additionally, I think it's among the most practical and useful classes for the future.

Weaknesses- not many other than the class was pretty big and sometimes we got bogged down into tedious questions.

I appreciated the structure of the homework assignments and exams, in that there was less pressure to perform well within a constrained environment (exams were all take-home, assignments were graded based on effort). Course material is practical and it's easy to see the applicability of course concepts to real life.
Couldn't fault it. Maybe could've moved a little quicker, but that is a personal preference which may not reflect the wider desire of the student body.
The class is great. It offers a different view on public health.
The course is excellent.
Excellent Course, Necessary Course for every MPH student
After going through this course, you can definitely feel that you've learned something and developed a new way of thinking. It is challenging, but in a good way.

Strengths (so many)
- The cases assigned as homework each week are actually directly relevant to what we learn in lecture and what is in the readings (which, by the way, are totally manageable)
- The professor is a riot (in the best way possible) 
- The lectures are well-delivered and actually hilarious at multiple points
- The content difficulty builds up at a comfortable pace
- Take-home exams are very fair and reflective of the homework (cases)

Weaknesses 
- The "flex" lecture left for the end of the semester is probably just better off decided by Prof. Paltiel instead of left to student suggestions.

Overall, one of the strongest courses at YSPH. The take-home exams format worked out well.   Also, thank you for recording. It helped to go over lectures multiple times while taking the exams. 

As for weakness, I did think that the first few homework assignments, which involved us struggling through content and then actually going through it during class, could be given some consideration. That is, could we do a similar problem during class and then have an associated problem set building on that? 
That seemed to be how the later classes were run, but I most definitely appreciated going over the answers and problem-solving in class to help clarify and allow space for questions. To that end, I'm not sure what format is best. I was honestly surprised at how much I learned.  I wish that David taught a  Spring semester course to continue to expand and crystallize  this skill set.
Very good class! Loved the problem set based set up.
Amazing instructor and strong course structuring.
excellent course

strengths: great professor, very charismatic, very helpful in office hours
weaknesses: having it online made me not attend lecture, therefore i didn't gain anything out of this course, i just watched the lectures right before exam time (mostly because i was overstretched this semester). i was hoping to learn more tangible skills. it's really up to the student to decide how much time they want to dedicate to the class. i therefore wish that lecture wasn't recorded so it would force me to attend and pay attention
The weekly homework assignments were a good way to practice concepts taught in class. I wished there was an opportunity for individualized feedback on the homework.

Wonderful instructor, clearly an expert on this topic and very passionate about it. His professional work in cost-effectiveness in HIV is fascinating and it's cool to see that his publications have made concrete policy changes in this country. He also does a good job simplifying these topics for students. Funny and engaging, really shows he cares about our learning.
Dr. Paltiel knows how to teach! I love his teaching style and you learn from the step-by-step demonstrations. Thank you so much for the fun classes.
Fun and engaging to listen to!  I think the late hour of the course made everyone a bit more tired than we all would have been otherwise.
He is outstanding. Best professor Ive had at Yale. Passionate about content and teaching, brilliant, and effective in delivering content.
My favourite course and instructor this term!! He was very engaging and his excitement for the content and class was infectious.

I loved Dr. Paltiel's style of lecturing and learned a lot from him in this course. I appreciated his willingness to meet outside of class as well as his positive attitude. It was clear that he loves teaching and is highly invested in the learning of his students.
Great professor, speedy feedback, very nice, challenges students but is also very understanding

Dr. Paltiel is an amazing professor. He is so energetic and passionate about the topic that it makes others want to learn. I really enjoyed learning from him, and I appreciated that he also recorded his lectures for days that I could not attend class. I liked that we went through the homework problems in class, but as someone who likes to get things right the first time, I would have liked a little more guidance going into the homeworks.
very insightful
A recipe to make a Professor Paltiel: intelligent, good humor, sassiness, and supportive of students as individuals (not just HPM 570 students!).
I like David's class. Interesting and educational.

great professor, keeps us laughing, and definitely knows the material.

I do think there were some concepts here and there (probably the more theoretical ideas that others brought up as questions or that he explained in conjunction to his main material) were explained a little more. I often found myself confused and then felt he moved on quickly, so even when I rewatched the videos I was still confused. Other than that, he is a great professor.
-Super engaging, kind, funny, and helpful
Very funny and personable professor!

best part of this class is the professor - you can tell he puts a lot of time and effort into teaching this class and his energy is contagious (especially in an admittedly dry subject area). one of the best teachers at YSPH
Super good
Wonderful professor, very charismatic and good at presenting material as well. I appreciated his ability to engage students in topics that were not always very exciting.
He is really good at teaching and has a comfortable and cheerful class environment.
Professor Paltiel is the most engaging professor I have ever had, his energy and passion for the subject is contagious. I really enjoyed his method of teaching and how he walked through examples.
Professor Paltiel is so funny, charismatic, and obviously very smart. As YSPH struggles to learn how to teach large classes, professor Paltiel does a great job managing that and sets a great example.

Paltiel is an excellent professor. He is goofy, which makes a 2-hour evening class actually enjoyable. He is great at teaching the content and I like that he does a great job of breaking things down so it's easy to understand.

Professor Paltiel is most definitely the best professor to teach this course. I really enjoyed his humor, and I also loved the questions he gave us for the problem sets / exams. I wish I had gotten to know him better in person, but again, the class size was too big.
good
Very engaging and knowledgable about the course material.  Great teacher.
very energetic and engaging
Great professor. Obviously super passionate about what he does. Super helpful, provides a lot of resources. Definitely would like more professors like him!
Great. Nice to students.
He is a very welcoming professor who creates a learning environment with a perfect balance of being supportive but also challenging.

Strengths - enthusiasm was great
Split the class nicely between book reading, hard skills (excel), and his own research in which he used the concepts we learned. 

Weaknesses - timing between homework and lecture. It may be more beneficial to introduce the concept in greater detail before assigning the homework for new topics.
Fair, gave plenty of time for exams, although some exam questions were difficult and not closely enough related to class material.  Class itself is a good time since he is incredibly entertaining.
wonderful job. excellent teacher

Professor Paltiel is hands down the best professor I've had at Yale. He doesn't just make an 1hr 50 min lecture bearable, but he makes it fun! I've never been able to sit through such a long course and enjoy it so thoroughly. He explains things quite well and is entertaining throughout. He's so patient with questions and quite helpful. Take his course!
Awesome and engaging. At times can be a little short with students, but overall great

Hands down amazing professor! I absolutely loved his lectures. They were clear, engaging, and organized. He made the class so enjoyable with his awesome lecturing skills, pedagogy, and humor. He was also very helpful during office hours and willing to make time to meet students. He seemed to care a lot about the course and was open to feedback to improve the course.

People have told me how complex it is to teach a course on cost effective analysis. However, Dr. Paltiel did an excellent job synthesizing the material. He broke down the material so well, and his level of enthusiasm makes class so much fun. You can tell that he is very passionate about the material and wants to help the students any way he can. I'm definitely happy that I took this course.
Prof. Paltiel is very humourous. He can always attract my eyes during the class and help me better understanding the course materials. Thanks a lot!
Paltiel is a dynamic and engaging lecturer that made learning about tough materials much more enjoyable.
Dr. Paltiel is very engaging, informative, and does a wonderful job at clarifying concepts.  My concerns are with the course structure and not with Dr. Paltiel himself.
Dr. Paltiel was a fantastic professor. He made class enjoyable, answered student questions in a positive, helpful manner, and knew the material very well. One of the best professors at YSPH.

Professor Paltiel is absolutely great! He was super great at making the class enjoyable and putting everything we learned relevant to the larger scope of what all of us are learning for our MPHs. I think that his exams were also very fair in that he wasn't trying to trick us by any means but rather just trying to assess our knowledge which was really great! Professor Paltiel is also really nice about taking both class time and after class time to talk over the questions anyone has regarding the class material. He was also super super funny which made a 5-7 pm class way more bearable and made learning fun. Overall, Professor Paltiel made the class super amazing and fun to go to! (Also really appreciated that the class was podcasted in case I needed to rewatch something or couldn't go to lecture!)
Great
Professor Paltiel made this course worth it. He has a way of introducing new material with humor that makes you want to learn. Amazing instructor.
The instructor is kind and has a fine sense of humor. He organizes the course well.
Amazing professor. I wish all my professors were as entertaining and passionate about what they do.

David Paltiel is probably the only professor who could make a Wednesday 5-7 class a delight. He is engaging, funny, and excellent teacher, and runs a wonderful class. The assignments were practical and helpful to introduce course concepts, and the readings selected were pretty helpful. I came out of the class with a good conceptual understanding of the material, and am ready to learn some more methods in my future classes.
Enthusiastic, open minded, and highly-expert.

Professor Paltiel is highly entertaining to listen to. He engages students and from a purely lecturing perspective, he is probably one of the best I have had at Yale and I very much enjoyed his lectures. I also very much appreciate he understands the demands of other courses at Yale and structures this course in as convenient a way as possible in terms of assignments and exams. For me, the type of content he teaches is difficult to fully grasp at first glance but on reviewing the lecture videos it is evident that he is a great lecturer. My only criticism would be that on the one occasion I sought it, I don't feel he was overly helpful on an individual level with a fairly straightforward question. It felt slightly as though, "here's the course, it's a basic intro to CEA, here's the resources, don't ask me anything more unless you're really one of the star students in the class". I don't want that to come across as harsh, because he is a very pleasant person otherwise, but ultimately it's the vibe I got.
best instructor
Very energetic and fun teaching style.
He is a great instructor, very energetic and passionate about the work
the professor was very open to meeting with students outside of lecture and explaining content material. he is very knowledgeable and patient.
Dr. Paltiel is an excellent instructor who is receptive to student questions and is always willing to meet with students, whether about the course or just to discuss subjects of interest.
Incredible professor who cares greatly about his students. He is very engaging and stimulates classroom discussion. Provides many opportunities for students who struggle to catch up.
Great professor! Sometimes teaches a little bit slow though, which loses the attention span of some students during lecture.
David is amazing. He's incredibly funny, students feel free and safe to ask questions, and you can tell that he goes out of his way to support students' learning as much as possible. 11/10!
I enjoy taking his course.

Professor Paltiel is an incredibly talented teacher. He is very dynamic, and explains technical concepts in easily-digestible ways. He's also extremely humble, and I always appreciated when he asked for feedback, and noticed ways that he could improve in real-time.

I also really appreciated his willingness to record class and let us watch from home! For the record, I did not go to class once after the first session, but I watched every single recording.

Paltiel is nothing short of engaging and I appreciate the quirkiness. It is very apparent that his sole interest is to ensure that students understand the material and are able to grasp the concepts taught in class. I'm a Leafs fan so I can overlook the Habs deviancy, but all in all a phenomenal instructor.

David was very engaging and funny. He kept material from getting too dry and was always open to questions and feedback. He was very clear in his expectations for the class and was very reasonable with decisions.
David is really a nice and humorous teacher and taking his class is such a fun and enjoyable thing. also learnt a lot about the CEA. his explanations are very clear and easy to understand.
Top notch. I have never felt so engaged at 6pm on a Wednesday night
Fantastic.  An expert in the field.  Strong communicator.  A nice guy to boot.  Humble with good self awareness.
Dr. Paltiel was very knowledgable about his subject and his enthusiasm and desire to teach was clearly evident during every class session.
Love Professor Paltiel, he was an amazing instructor and explained everything to so well and in an entertaining manner too.

Professor Paltiel is really energetic and passionate about every class and his work. He also respect the students' feedbacks for every class and exam. The videos are also really good for us to follow up the class.

Strengths:
-makes a normally dry subject exciting and fun
-includes outside of class options for students who are doing well to grow their learning experience
-designs excel sheets that allow for students to try out methods outside of class

Weaknesses:
-Sometimes we spend too long in class on certain examples so that every last person in class understands the problem. It would be better for the larger class in general if those a handful of students who were struggling had their questions answered during office hours.
David was great to learn from. Entertaining, smart, great at taking questions, and made himself very available to meet with students outside of class. Joy to learn from.
Overall excellent!
Great, Paltiel makes the concepts more easily to understand, his teaching is concise and clear.

This course could be complicated, but Professor Paltiel makes it more understandable and offered us a detailed explanation with cases and examples. 
Also, his humor is really one thing keeps me in his class, I really enjoy the atmosphere in his class, more relaxable and interactive. 
One drawback might be, to some points, David may emphasize a bit more on the basics, and skip some more complicated concepts which are difficult to understand. 
Overall, David is an excellent professor and we love him very much.

Fantastic. Paltiel genuinely cares about his students. He was receptive to unscheduled walk-in meetings and took the time to have full conversations beyond just the scope of the weekly homework and the course content. Hes been a great mentor! Definitely my favorite professor of the semester.
Extremely kind, intelligent, enthusiastic about teaching - an integral presence at YSPH.

Dr. Paltiel is very responsive to feedback and cares a lot about students.  The classes were very enjoyable.  I liked that they were recorded, as I often watched them prior to an exam to better understand the topics.

AP: Strengths: Prof Paltiel is warm, engaging and funny and I enjoyed coming to his lectures. 

Weaknesses: The lecture slides need a refresh- when it came time to revise/tests it was difficult at times to get key information from the lecture slides, I found myself watching the lectures over and over again to find this information

AP-
Truly the most engaging and hilarious professor I have met. Felt like the first few weeks offered more key concepts than the ending, where there just seemed to be lots of review. Could have structured the course to have more material towards the end!
Professor Paltiel encourages learning for the sake of learning and not for grades. He also made the class engaging and has no weaknesses.
Entertaining, interesting fake and real world examples of the techniques (and failures) of CEA/CBA.
Professor Paltiel was absolutely incredible. He is extremely knowledgeable, caring, and funny! It is easy to tell he cares about teaching and loves the course material.

He's a great lecturer and definitely has a lot to offer his students. His problem sets and exams are very thoughtful and he makes lectures very interesting. I would have maybe liked more practice problems and solutions if possible, especially when we started off with decision trees.
Professor Paltiel is fantastic. Really, take this class.
Professor Paltiel was an engaging professor, and he did a good job of making complex subjects understandable. He gave me helpful, detailed answers when I had questions about the class.
He is funny and professional.

Strengths: He is so funny and approachable. Also I appreciate that he goes slowly.
Weaknesses: While he is always helpful in email, sometimes can come across as a bit annoyed (maybe my question is obvious though).
The instructor is extremely knowledgeable about his subject matter and very engaging. I enjoyed that he spoke about his own work and publications.

STRENGTHS
-- Paltiel is an AMAZING lecturer, dynamic and enthusiastic and clear. Mic drop moments every 10 minutes. Should have been a stand-up comedian, but instead decided to be a professor where his talents are wasted ;)
-- The professor took into account student input throughout the semester and responded to it. He responded promptly to students questions.
-- The professor was warm and friendly to students, and demonstrably knowledgeable.
-- The professor described real-world situations and issues in lectures, so we could see how the use of cost-effectiveness analysis plays out in understanding problems and making decisions.

WEAKNESSES
-- N/A.
excellent
Fantastic, very engaging, clear and helpful.
Dr. Paltiel was very entertaining in class and explained things very clearly.

Very entertaining, the type of entertaining that can only come from a high level of mastery with a subject. Clearly enjoys teaching and knows that students are more engaged if they are having fun learning. Can occasionally get on some tangential rants, but it comes with the territory I suppose. Very much enjoyed him as a professor.

Professor Paltiel is an excellent instructor - he's hilarious, easy to follow in his coverage of course material, and very open to feedback from students. I think his teaching played a huge role in making the course concepts interesting and digestible.
great

Dr. Paltiel is friendly and helpful. Although it's a big class, he tries to take care of everyone in the class. He stops periodically during lectures to answer questions. The materials covered throughout the semester are mathy, but he made it quite fun and easy to understand. He is open to feedbacks.
I really enjoyed the course and thought Professor Paltiel is was an excellent instructor.
He is excellent at teaching and very funny. He is willing to help his students.
Engaging Lecturer
Very engaging and easy to learn from. Also very approachable and knowledgeable.

OMG DAVID PALTIEL IS AWESOME SAUCE! 
Seriously, even if you aren't super thrilled about the idea of cost-effectiveness analysis, Prof. Paltiel's gift for teaching will turn you into a fan! He knows his stuff and this is so obvious in the confidence with which he deliver's his humor-filled lectures. What a gem! A blessing to YSPH!

Engaging and a hoot! Thank you for making a topic that is intimidating, accessible to the masses.  In terms of improvement, I'd like to see a greater variety of examples discussed. Integrating climate change would be beneficial for future students.
He is awesome! Very clear and enthusiastic
Clear, very enthusiastic, good at simplifying concepts.
incredible professor, very helpful, funny, charming, pushes you to succeed and learn the material, i recommend without reservation

Super knowledgeable and engaging with good examples. 
However, when there were concepts that were confusing to the class, they were not always clearly explained using simple language.
An interesting style of teaching

Great course for any healthcare student interested in the policy/economics side of the industry. Highly recommend if you are less experienced in this area - for those who already have significant economic/data analysis experience - David does recommend higher-level courses at YSPH and SOM.
I highly recommend this class to other students. It's fun and practical.

This course could be easy or difficult depending on your learning style and ability to be comfortable with answers that are not absolutely "correct."  Students should take this discomfort seriously and not misplace it onto the instructor or the TFs when in reality it is the material that is difficult.  Making time to individually clarify is important because of the size of the class--you must put effort in to get feedback.  Overall, I would recommend it because I think it is a unique course that combines principles of mathematics with principles of politics and is difficult but interesting in this way.  Additionally, learning from Professor Paltiel is a joy and an experience!

Extremely helpful for getting cost effectiveness background knowledge and improving excel skills. Fantastic professor. It is more of a time commitment than some YSPH courses but it would be a mistake to skip taking this course.
it's a great intro class to decision making!
Highly recommended!! Not only was it very enjoyable, but I learned a lot and hope to include some aspect of CEA in my research work in the future.
I would recommend this course to a fellow student.
Great course if you're interested in decision making!

This is a great course!!! Especially for those who are not in Health Policy, this course is super useful to understand how decisions are made in the real world. Many times, SBS focuses on the interventions, but doesn't think about why specific interventions were chosen or the intricacies of the cost/benefit analysis. This class helped me to understand the technical views of public health. This class also helps future health professionals gain a better understanding of health behaviors, and why some people may choose to do certain things though the "cost" may be higher.
recomment
Somewhat time-intensive (less than you probably think at the beginning of the semester though). Rewarding. A step outside of most YSPH classes.
must-to-take at YSPH
-It was a challenging course that helped build your problem solving skills, it is worthwhile to take as the professor is wonderful
Recommend to non-quantitative students
Really great class for anyone looking to learn more about this topic, whether they are an HPM student or not I would highly recommend!
An interesting class.
Highly recommend but make sure to put in the work! You have to watch the lectures, do the homeworks, and keep up in order to do well.

Absolutely take this course. I was at first not going to take this because I was already going to take Public Health Law - but I last minute decided to take this course as well, and it's the best decision I've made this semester. If you enjoy quantitative thinking, don't be scared, you will enjoy it.
Excellent course, definitely worth taking. I've recommended it to all of my friends.
Highly, highly recommend.
good
This course makes you think. definitely an interesting course

Recorded lectures, homeworks are completion (you don't even have to get the right answer, you can explain what you would do, which is really helpful in learning the material after he goes over it in class). Exams are take home. Professor is great. Would definitely recommend the class.
Great

I would definitely recommend taking this course to other students. I would tell my classmates that it is course that provides background on sum of the topics we touch on in epi, biostats, and health policy. In epi and biostats we discuss screening and decision making briefly whereas this course dives into that concept further, which I found very interesting. Health policy briefly discusses cost-effectiveness analysis and so it was enjoyable to get a better grasp on what CEA really is by being in this course.

A great introduction to decision making with very practical skills taught in the class using a platform most people are somewhat familiar with, Excel. The professor was always enthusiastic and entertaining while also thoroughly covering his material. He also answered any questions during lecture or in office hours and is always open to suggestions for topics that the class is interested in. I would definitely recommend to anyone in any degree seeking program.

I would not recommend if you are not a big numbers person in a different department.  I took the course because I heard great things about Dr. Paltiel.  They were all true.  He is funny and entertaining and gives an engaging lecture.  However, I struggled through the difficult material.  Definitely take if this will be useful to your career or you are interested in the topic, but I would avoid if this is not the case as the exams can be difficult.
really good
Take it! It's useful material. Just be sure to keep up with the material and lectures and ask lots of questions when encessary

This class is super fun, informative, useful, and engaging. If you are into cost effectiveness analysis and modeling, this class is a good start. I definitely taking a class with Professor Paltiel any time you can during your time at Yale. He's probably one of the best professors here. The skills you get from the course can be very applicable and useful.

I would highly recommend this, because it has an application in so many public health and medicine fields. Whenever we want to evaluate an intervention or novel solution, cost is something that always pops up as a key deciding factor. The instructor has done a very fine job in designing this course, and I feel like I can apply the concepts from this course to my work in the future.

I will recommend this course to another student since this course enlarged my horizon to think about public health issues at the cost-effectiveness level. That's the thing I have never imagined before. It's very helpful.

I would only recommend this course if you actually see yourself pursuing modeling/data analysis long term in your career interests.  A lot of students recommend this course but I find that they do this because Dr. Paltiel is charismatic and engaging.  Don't waste $60,000/year on courses just because the professors are charismatic.  Spend that money on courses because you actually see them being beneficial to your long-term interests.

This course taught students how to make rational, cost-effective decisions in the health care setting. You definitely learn hard skills in this class. I would recommend this class if you really want to hone in on learning how to make these decisions in a methodical manner. There is not too much information in this course, rather than learning this skill.

Summarize: this class teaches you both what and how to run cost-effectiveness analyses, using excel. I would definitely recommend to another student because you can learn so much and you don't really have to have too much prior knowledge, e.g. advanced calculus or coding experience. Everything that we learn is definitely new (to most of us, I'd imagine) but super manageable and ultimately gives you a lot of awesome skills if you are going to be doing your own research or just analyzing existing data.
I would recommend
Highly recommend
This course introduced basic knowledge on cost-effectiveness analysis and decision making. It is really an interesting course. Highly recommended.

Take this class. If you're not familiar with cost-effectiveness analysis, this will blow your mind in some ways. It is a very interesting way to think about decisions in healthcare, and a useful language to know! I just expected an interesting class, and now I think that cost-effectiveness analysis will be a fairly significant part of my career!
Highly recommend
Good Professor, good intro to CEA. Course is structured well in terms of assignments etc. Overall, would recommend.
I don't know how people leverage if they should take this or Policy Modeling. I find this course easy to understand and very straightforward (even I do not get full mark for any of the exams).
I enjoyed the material and instructor, it was one of my favorite courses this semester
Overall I would recommend the course if you are interested in learning the basic theories and concepts in decision analysis/making in a healthcare setting.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. It is interesting and adds another dimension to public health.
Great course that covers a lot of important topics. More challenging than your typical YSPH course.

Useful in building a toolkit of different strategies to evaluate cost-effectiveness of programs and to analyze/think critically about how to provide value in healthcare. Not too heavy of a workload, interesting lectures, and exams are fun/challenging. Would recommend!

This is an incredibly useful course with a star professor. Would recommend to anyone and everyone! Not only do you learn how to go about decision-making and cost effectiveness analyses, you also think critically about priorities and how to make those judgment calls with competing priorities!
This is the most interesting course I've took for this semester. The instructor makes the course very relax and flexible. For students good at math, the material is a little bit easy.

This is a great class to develop a mindset for decision analysis, and get some practice with the basic quantitative tools. People seem to fall into two camps: those for whom this makes sense instantly, and those for whom it's a big challenge. I would say that if this comes easily to you, this is a low-investment opportunity to get some practice and exposure to new types of analyses. If this is challenging for you, this is probably the ideal environment to give it a try. Either way, I highly recommend the class!
The material was not what I was expecting but I did end up enjoying the class. The instructor was very engaging so going to class was very enjoyable. I would recommend it.
strongly recommend! not only have great knowledge, also would fall in love with the teacher!!!
Essential course.  Well taught.  Show up to class, put in the work.  You will learn a lot.

This class should be a requirement to every student in the public health school. Cost-effectiveness applies to all areas of public health and healthcare and I find that I'm using the concepts and I learned every day in my work.
It is an introduction class to cost-effectiveness. Good class good teacher.

This course is a great course for students looking for an intro to cost effective methods, either as someone hoping to grow their modeling experience or have a sample of the topic. The professor is considerate of students and really wants students to understand the material.

Definitely recommend for students to take. Great class that teaching a unique concept at YSPH that you won't learn elsewhere. This course can be challenging for those who are weaker with statistics, but worthwhile to take.
I'd recommend it.
I would recommend this course since it can teach you the basic knowledge for cost effectiveness analysis and help you to understand how to conduct it in solving the real problem.
Yes, I would recommend this course to a fellow student. This course could offer you a broad concept of what cost-effective analysis is, and how shall we conduct it.

I would highly recommend this course to any first years looking for an elective. This course is super useful in the internship search process and helped me land a position early on in the year. The course is not easy but an honors is definitely doable with due diligence and consistent effort. Paltiel is a great professor.
Super hard, but very important material for any concentration. Be prepared to budget big blocks of time, and get to know the professor early (and attend class!!!!)
Great course if you enjoy math and are interested in this topic.  Be prepared to work hard to understand the concepts.
AP: Good overview of decision analysis, I enjoyed this course overall

AP-
Lots of interesting concepts! Front-loaded course work. Highly entertaining and engaging professor.
Fair assessments.
One of the best courses offered at YSPH taught by an excellent professor.

Very interesting and stimulating class. Homeworks are done before the lecture on the material which is different, but they are doable after doing the reading (usually 1-2 articles/chapters in PDF format per week). I think the pace could've been faster but overall the quality of Dr Paltiel's teaching is very high.
I think it's great and people should take it!
I would take it to learn the skills if you feel it would helpful in your line of work.

CEA teaches you new ways of viewing and thinking about evidence. As evidence is the currency of all public health professionals, this course should be mandatory for anyone pursuing an MPH. Seriously, take this class.

I would recommend to this course to someone who has an introductory knowledge of probability but has little to no knowledge of cost-effectiveness analysis as applied to healthcare. Having a working knowledge of probability is not necessary to succeed in the class, but it is definitely helpful.
Yes. Because its very usefully and teacher is very funny.
You will learn the fundamentals of cost effectiveness analysis. I would recommend it because it is very practical
Overall I enjoyed the course, I felt the subject matter was interesting and the instructor was engaging. I do wish the class size had been smaller.
I would recommend taking this course because the measure of cost-effectiveness is thrown around a lot, but do you actually know how to apply and interpret it? If not, this course is for you.

Everyone must take this course. It brings in a little game theory, a little economics, a little epidemiology, lots of really good stuff you need to know. I learned more from cost-effectiveness analysis than from any other class at YSPH.
really helpful course, excellent instructor
Great course for learning about medical/public health decision-making, but still seems some depth is missing in terms of rigor.
I would highly recommend this to other students who are looking to build on their quantitative analysis skills.
Provided a good method to think about decision making and some useful practical tools that can be applied out in the business/medicine fields.
Highly recommended for any MPH student - course material is very applicable to real life and there are ample opportunities to ask for help whenever things get confusing!
An excellent foray into a huge part of health policy, which I could easily recommend to another student.

It is a relatively big class, and it's recorded. The instructor does not require attendance, and the exams are online. So you can consider it as an online class. The instructor is friendly and helpful. I would recommend this class to anyone interested.
The course is good and very introductory to students, no strong background is needed.
Great Course

This course provides a strategic way to think about which programs/policies to use in public health given the different costs and benefits of each program/policy. I would definitely recommend it to other students as cost-effectiveness is something we should all consider in this field.

Even if you are remotely interested in how different parameters (such as cost, outcome, etc) can be used to set up a process for decision-making in medicine or health generally, I HIGHLY recommend you take this awesome course! You'll never want to miss lecture, and as long as you make sure you are understanding the material in the case each week, the exams will be doable!
Take this course. It is a privilege to learn from an instructor as skilled and enthusiastic as David.
Great overview of cost effectiveness
excellent
i recommend this course to students based on professor paltiel; he's second to none and really makes dull content so fun

It is a really difficult class, which will require heavy work every single week. The homework questions and midterm questions are typically 10x harder than the examples he gives in class and there is little online help since he effectively designed the class himself.
I would recommend this course to students who have an interest in learning about how to health care decisions are made with cost-effectiveness considerations in mind.
